citation.article-title: Leucobacter celer sp. nov., isolated from Korean fermented seafood
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Leucobacter celer sp. nov.
Leucobacter celer (ce′ler. L. masc. adj. celer rapid, indicating rapid growth)
Cells are Gram-reaction-positive, aerobic, irregular-rod-shaped and non-motile.
After 48 h of incubation on TSA at 37 °C, colonies are circular, cream coloured, smooth, opaque, convex and 0.8–1.2 mm in diameter with entire margins.
Growth occurs at 4–45 °C, at pH 5–10 and in the presence of 0–12 % (w/v) NaCl.
Optimal growth occurs at 37 °C, pH 8 and 0 % NaCl.
Grows on TSB containing up to 20 mM Cr (VI).
Utilizes Tweens 40 and 80, d-ribose, d-xylose, pyruvic acid, l-alaninamide, putrescine and glycerol (Biolog GP2).
Aesculin ferric citrate and gelatin are hydrolysed (API 20 NE) and d-glucose, d-fructose, d-mannose, inositol, aesculin, gluconate and 5-ketogluconate (API 50 CH) are assimilated.
The major cellular fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, anteiso-C17 : 0 and iso-C16 : 0.
The cell-wall amino acids are DAB, alanine, threonine, glycine, and glutamic acid.
The predominant menaquinone is MK-11; minor components are MK-9 and MK-10.
The polar lipids are DPG, PG, and GL.
The type strain, NAL101T ( = KACC 14220T = JCM 16465T), was isolated from gajami-sikhae, a traditional Korean fermented food.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 68.8 mol%.
